As the wind would blow, the kids would get speckled with soot. They washed off in the water. We later found the sign indicating that the water may be contaminated due to surface runoff. Thankfully none of the children became ill.

Reviews.Title: “Mixed Experience”
Reviews.Author: FamilyTravelMom
Reviews.Content: Stayed in a bayfront King with sofabed 3/27 -3/30. Room was o.k. and could have used cleaning (especially carpets and walls) and fresh paint. Floor space was very tight. We could not walk throught the room from our king bed to the bathroom when the sofabed was opened. We literally had to crawl over the sofabed as there was zero floorspace to walk on. The view of the bay from our room was very beautiful; however, lots of jelly fish in the bay and on the beach (act of nature not the hotel). We enjoyed an evening campfire in the fire ring on the beach which was near our room. Campfire supplies (wood, matches, marshmellows, etc.) were pricey at the hotel store. Of the many pools, only the main pool was heated therefore it is very crowded. We had planned to play mini-golf, but it is age restricted to age 8 and older (our 4 year old loves to play). Parking is $20 per night. I found a package that included free parking and a $36/day credit at the casual restaurant. The casual restaurant is convenient, but slow and pricey. Plan to spend $50 for 2 adults, 2 kids for breakfast or lunch. Dinner is more expensive. Basic Cocktails were $10 each. Kids meals do not include beverage. Milk is $3.50. Plan to drive 10-15 minutes to other restaurants off property. Despite the prices and "tired" room condition, I was happy with the hotel until the last night. Our room was invaded by tiny ants! After seeing hundreds of ants, I called the front desk. They offered to come spray the room, but I didn't want freshly sprayed poison in our room as we were ready to go to sleep. The person at the front desk said they spray for ants with "Windex". I found this to be completely unbelievable. No other rooms were available for us to move to. Furthermore, the front desk person said that "ants were to be expected." For me, the ants were the final straw. I will not return to this hotel. I have stayed in 2 other hotels in the San Diego area and never had ants. We had a great time for 2 nights, but we knew and accepted that this resort was expensive due to it's beachfront, single story accomodations (truly a different experience than staying in a multi-story hotel). I guess we pushed our luck by staying the 3rd night. We saw cleaning crews with extermination sprayers. Perhaps, they exterminate after every guest checks out.

Reviews.Title: “Relaxing oasis with some minor flaws”
Reviews.Author: ATSChicago
Reviews.Content: Recently stayed at the Paridise Point in San Diego with my wife and two daughters. Overall, we enjoyed our stay. The grounds are beautiful and spacious with birds of paradise flowers everywhere the eye can see. We took advantage of all the property offered including swimming pool, spa, tennis, biking, miniature golf, beach and basketball. Food was good but as typical for this type of resort; prices were just north of outrageous. Ditto for spa services. Staff was very accommodating and always pleasant. The primary complaint for us surrounds the rooms. The bed was awful and the sleeper sofa bed was worse. Uncomfortable bedding and poor sleep really had a big effect on our vacation. In general the rooms could use some enhancements as it relates to furnishings and amenities to justify the price.

Reviews.Title: “Had a good time at the conference”
Reviews.Author: jasper87
Reviews.Content: We just returned from staying at the Paradise Point Resort, and I didn't find the negatives the other posters had mentioned, other than the typical resort charges. My room was very comfortable in Hibiscus Village, and housekeeping was attentive and thorough. The weather wasn't all that great, but that's not something they control. Almost every staff member we encountered as polite, helpful and friendly. I was impressed. Our meals were good. The resort was hard to navigate at first, so rely on your map. The only negatives are typical resort charges -- parking charges for a "nearby" spot (however, the Hyatt charges much more for a parking garage -- at least these spots are close to the room), and the pricing in the bars. Soda was $4, and domestic beer was $7. My friend had a margarita, and it was almost $10. That was a bit steep. Overall, we had a pleasant stay. I'd stay here again.

Reviews.Title: “Amazing Spa Experience”
Reviews.Author: bitties
Reviews.Content: I went to the Spa Terre for my sister's bachelorette party--it was amazing! the entire place is beautiful, and you feel so removed and secluded from the busy San Diego area. The grounds are gorgeous, very clean and well maintained. The staff was so nice--we have 11 women who all changed their reservations and spa treatements many times, and the Spa staff (Erin the manager is so sweet) completely accommodated all our requests. I reccommend reserving the private area--they served us with fresh fruit and vegetables, and we spent the day in our own private wood spa filled with flowers. I also reccommend the Chococlate Ice Cream pedicure and a facial with Melodie. We sat in the spa, layed out by the pool, and spent time in both the wet and dry saunas. But be warned: it IS really expensive, the entire resort is not cheap, but completely worth it (and I LIVE in San Diego). My boyfriend and I are going for a weekend just to be pampered and get away from life. If you're stressed, it is totally worth every penny. I can't wait to go again.

Reviews.Title: “Bugs and cold water showers”
Reviews.Author: ellee
Reviews.Content: We stayed here for 3 nights last week for a business conference, and were not impressed. The 'street map' the front desk provided was totally inaccurate and not-to-scale, and we drove around in circles trying to find our room, which was in a building that resembled a cement bunker. We were forever getting lost in the maze, and found it very inconvenient to get anywhere on the 'campus'. It was inconvenient for a conference b/c it was a 5 minute walk to get anywhere with poor signage along the way. There were mini ant-like bugs crawling around the room, on the sink, on our tooth brushes, over the desk and the coffee table. I remarked to my husband the first morning that I had probably eaten a few in my sleep! The daily charges of $20 for parking and $15 for the fitness center were ridiculous!! The first morning we both commented on the great water-pressure in the shower, but the next day the water was luke-warm, and was cold on the last morning. The only good thing about this was that when we complained about the cold water they took the $60 parking charge off our bill! $60 to park in the deserted lot 100 feet from our room. We were also disappointed that there was no wireless internet available. We took turns plugging into the one ethernet cable in the room (remarkably they did not charge for using the ethernet cable; perhaps they overlooked that). The room did have a great big walk-in closet, but only 8 hangers, so it did not do us much good. The decor was rustic country, which surprised me for a Southern California hotel. There was a couch and coffee table, and 2 uncomfortable wicker chairs. The doors of the large hutch containing the fridge and tv could not be opened all the way b/c they hit the footboard on the bed. I did enjoy the view out to the patio at the back of our room, which was very private and nicely planted. Unfortunately it was only 60 degrees out so we could not sit out there.

Reviews.Title: “Purgatory Point Would Be More Accurate”
Reviews.Author: TripBlazer
Reviews.Content: I would echo the previous review in every detail. "Prepare to be gouged" is spot-on. $20/day for a parking spot (see photo) -- not even for valet parking, but just to park yourself next to your room. $15/day for the tiny exercise room. Yes, that's per day, not per stay. You get one day's fee off if you book one of the overpriced "spa" packages. Big deal, since the spa services themselves cost many times what they would cost in the outside world. And the prices at their "casual" outdoor restaurant are what you would normally expect from a fine dining experience. My wife and I spent $73 for two appetizers, two soups (nearly inedible), one order of luke-warm, flavorless coffee, and two salads that we split -- no main course. Our room was nothing special, though the rate was what we normally spend in Hawaii. The bathroom paint was disintegrating and peeling off, the hinges on the door were completely rusted, and the furniture was shabby at best. What the previous reviewer didn't mention is that this is one of those resorts where everything is inconveniently located -- it's all spread out over many acres. Your room is likely to be in a little building far from the main lobby, spa, exercise room, pool, meeting rooms, and restaurants. To do anything, you have to walk outside and walk or drive to the facilities. So if you want to be overcharged for the room, charged extra for every amenity, and inconvenienced in accessing any of them, this is the place for you.

Reviews.Title: “It was alright”
Reviews.Author: cliffwy
Reviews.Content: The rooms were ok. I walked in and found a small spider in the bathroom. The toilet looked "used". The carpet must not have been vacuumed as I found a half eaten pretzel in the middle of the room. Parking (which I was not aware of) was $20 for one night (I heard it's $10/night for extended stays). I was not expecting to pay for parking. Shower was nice (rain shower), but the hot water ran out quickly. All in all, my stay was ok. I traveled there on business, but in the summer months, it would probably be very nice for a family as there is much to do there.

Reviews.Title: “Prepare to be gouged!”
Reviews.Author: Homelytraveler
Reviews.Content: Upon entering the property we were awestruck by the tropical island-like surroundings--truly believed we had made an excellent deal by selecting an Alaska Airlines vacation package including air fare and hotel. The photos we had seen online didn't actually do the place justice. We found ourselves surrounded by towering palm trees, huge flowering shrubs, natural-looking lagoons, ponds and fountains, with strategic patios on which to relax next to flowing waters. The curbside valets and bell staff were cordial and accomodating; however, our first nasty surprise came in the sumptuous lobby upon registering, when we learned that it would cost $20.00 per night-no exceptions--to park our rental car in front of our room--or anywhere on the property, in fact. The desk clerk informed us that this was clearly stated on their web site (news to us). With no other parking within a reasonable walking distance, we had no choice but to pay. This added another $100.00 to the cost of our five-day stay. After traveling since early morning, we were more than ready for lunch at 3 p.m. on the day of our arrival, and seated ourselves at the outdoor restaurant. Our hamburger and sandwich lunch with iced tea came to $50.00, (including a modest tip for modest service). We were even billed for refills on the tea! That was our first and last meal at the resort. The rooms are motel style. An inaccessable outdoor light shone through the door window all night long, making it impossible to truly darken our room. "Shabby chic" best describes the decor. This included the armoir holding the TV, fridge and our clothing, and shabby it was: the white finish was marred by nasty black marks at the base and appeared to be rotting in places. One drawer was askew, leaving nearly a one-inch gap above one side of the closed drawer, and using it was a chore at best. (With bilateral tennis elbow, I had to ask my husband to pull it out and push it back in.) The bathroom door molding was completely rotted away in places. The mirror over the single sink was lighted by two 52-watt bulbs (yes, that's 52)--good luck grooming with that kind of illumination. The weather that week was not conducive to lazing by the pool but , if memory serves, available television programming consisted of MSNBC, CNBC, CNN, Headline News, the Discovery and Disney channels, and the standard local network outlets --oh, and, of course, a pay-per-view movie channel; there was no channel listing on-screen or on paper; NBC had a distinct orange cast at all times; the audio interference was often so severe that it was impossible to follow the program. ABC was sometimes watchable, but often there was no picture. All of the channels featured annoying audio interference to varying degrees. We registered complaints the second, third and fourth days of our stay. "Engineers" came to our room twice to tell us someone was "working on the problem" but by the fifth and last day of our stay, nothing had changed. The concierge was available only to those standing in front of him. Calling on the phone meant sitting on hold until we gave up. and looked for other information resources. So, if you're thinking of a nice resort vacation at Paradise Point, be prepared to pay through the nose and be higly self-sufficient; don't be disappointed when your accomodations fail to be on a par with the lobby or the grounds.

Reviews.Title: “Businees for the hubby, pleasure for me”
Reviews.Author: odilelosaltos
Reviews.Content: true ,the hotel looks like it needs some freshing up. We had a room on the bayside, lg living room ,big bathroom ,av bedroom, small kitchen with a microwave. I had a spa treatment nice not too expensive. nice staff, I used the restaurant barefoot grill for breakfast, it was gd. We had a couple of receptions and the food was great and plentiful. You do need a car , you are pretty isolated . I would love to go back especially after the renovation in June

Reviews.Title: “Not worth the money”
Reviews.Author: Jamie_Cincinnati
Reviews.Content: I stayed here for a conference. The conference facilities and food was pretty good. The grounds were nice and well-kept. The hotel rooms, however, were horrendous especially for the price. The first night, I was rudely awakened at midnight by lawn sprinklers going off in front of my door. In addition, I was awakened about every two hours because the smoke detector kept making noise. I called the front desk the next morning to let them know and they changed the battery. The small refrigerator was also very noisy and you could hear what was going on in your neighbor's room. In addition, at 7 a.m. on Friday morning I couldn't get any hot water. Friday night wasn't much better - although the smoke detector didn't make noise the room was still very noisy from other things. This place is definitely not worth the price and I wouldn't stay here for pleasure.

Reviews.Title: “A secluded, rustic resort.”
Reviews.Author: JamieD22
Reviews.Content: A great experience if the price is right. Keep in mind that anything the resort has to offer will come at a cost. Secondly, if you're expecting luxury, you'll be disappointed. I booked a room for 4 nights in January for my fiance and myself, so that we could get married on the property during our stay. That said, the grounds of the hotel are immaculate and masterfully kept. The rooms however are old, a bit out-dated, and would probably classify as "rustic" sooner than "nice." I might go as far as to say "cozy." The hotel is not for those who couldn't book their room at the Hilton but more for those who want a more secluded, outdoorsy, almost camp-like resort. The ammenities on the grounds are laughably expensive; the spa, the workout facility, the restaurants... there were too many alternatives in nearby La Jolla to spend money on the resort. There is a parking fee of $20 per day though the front desk charged us only $10 (due to the length of our stay). Other than that we were offered nothing special (which I found a bit odd considering the nature of our visit). We stayed in the "Lanai Garden" (base room) for 2 nights, then paid extra the last 2 nights to stay on the beach in the "Lanai Bayside." It was worth the extra $50 per night, and it took only a few minutes to coordinate, though I felt slighted having to pay - the resort was practically empty and again it would have been a nice gesture. All in all we had a very memorable visit. The hotel is centrally located but secluded from the surrounding attractions. My tip would be to take a drive north on Hwy 101, stopping off at all the quaint beach towns. Balboa park is a lot of fun, too, just get out & explore!

Reviews.Title: “Very good if you get a deal”
Reviews.Author: momdadkiddog
Reviews.Content: I've read the widely varying reviews on this resort. Now having stayed there, I think I can be helpful to sort out the disparities. First, I think it helps to know about the reviewer. I'm comfortable in a clean Motel 6, but stay about once every six months in $300 and up resorts. Cleanliness and no deferred maintenance is paramount to me. Service is important, but I'm satisfied if the resort "makes it right for mistakes, as long as there are only one or two that don't greatly affect the purpose for my stay. I hate overpaying, but don't mind paying a lot if I get something special for the price. So with that in mind... The first impression driving up to the resort is very impressive. You meander up a beautiful private drive, with well manicured and landscaped grounds. The check in building is OK. There was a snafu immediately at check-in. I couldn't determine if it was the fault of the resort or the agent, but all was straighten out ,with much apology, in about 1/2 hour, a bit long for a tired family. If you arrived on public transportation someone in an oversized golf cart will take you to your room. You'll need it. Even if you drive, ask for someone to guide you to your room, especially at night. You WILL get lost on your own. Because of the package I booked, our room was probably on the lower-end pricing end of what's available. Considering the on-line pictures, I was disappointed at the drive-up appeal of the bungalow: fronting on a parking lot, although concealed by some attractive landscaping. Once inside, I found the room small, but very appealing, recently updated, with warm materials, and thoughtful interior decorating. The bathroom was well-done. All was spotlessly clean. Ask for a room with a water view. Many rooms have none, despite what you'd think from their pictures. It looks like the water-view rooms would make most people very happy. We were in San Diego during record cold, so opted out of visiting the pools which looked attractive. There are two main restaurants. I highly recommend breakfast at the Barefoot Bar and Grill. It reminds me of some of the nicer open-air resort restaurants in Hawaii with surround-views of Mission Bay, sea-water pools containing large native fish, and ubigitous, gulls, terns, herons and egrets standing by ready for any scraps your children care to share. Food and service were excellent, but we chose a low-volume time to dine. I don't know if they get busy. The putt-putt course is a unique, natural grass course with some very long putting between holes. It looks entertaining. Great views of Mission Bay from the climb-up observatory. If you're taking kids to Sea World you can't get much closer than this resort. Service overall was fair, not great for the price. My impression is they're somewhat understaffed. For example we ordered room service that took over one hour, and they never responded to our call to pick up the tray. We called back to tell them we'd leave it outside and it remained there overnight - spread around and picked over by gulls. The overall quality is very good, but not Four Seasons good. If you haven't been to many high-end resorts I think you'll be delighted. If you're used to high end service you'll be a little or a lot disappointed. Bottom line. If you can get a deal, I think it's well-worth it. But if you'll pay much more than $150/night for the basic room, I'd shop.

Reviews.Title: “not worthy to stay”
Reviews.Author: Plasmodium
Reviews.Content: the room is very old and terrible, we don't even have a coffee maker. we stay there for two days, but our room card has been blocked when we return the room at first night. I think it is not worthy for a four star hotel. i will not recommend people to stay there. There're plenty of hotels in San Diego, one can go anyone but just not this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Your Safety Doesn't Matter”
Reviews.Author: UDXMXJ
Reviews.Content: Paradise Point Resort and Spa, San Diego, CA Beware that the management at this resort does not care about your safety. While I was there in September of 2006 I fell on an eroded strip of grass and broke my wrist. This is a long narrow strip of grass between several units and the beach. My small grandchildren had also been tripping and falling in that same area. The only thing I asked of the resort management was that they rope off this area and get the grass filled in and fixed as soon as possible. As of January 2007, they have refused to acknowledge that this dangerous area is a hazard and have done nothing to eliminate the hazard for other guests. I have written twice to remind them of their moral obligation to ensure the safety of other guests but they have refused to act and have added insult to injury by inferring that my pain was distorting my evaluation of the situation. Can fourteen family members all staying at this resort and in this location all be wrong in their evaluation that the area is hazardous? The resort is also overpriced and the parking you pay for is a numbered spot beside your unit.

Reviews.Title: “Great Place!”
Reviews.Author: trip56
Reviews.Content: It was great place to stay. The cottage/room was just a walk to the beach. The drive to the cottage/room was a nice change from traditional hotels. There were heated pools and spa. Friendly and helpful hosts and crew. Lots of little lagoon and bridges for a nice walk. I specially enjoyed the Christmas lights they have by the registration building. A little bit pricey but it was worth the stay. Except the room only had two bath towels and a hand towel. The key didn't work an hour before check time so be careful being locked out.

Reviews.Title: “Wow, Yes!!!”
Reviews.Author: themusicman
Reviews.Content: We were looking for somewhere warm to relax before the real winter set in in Scotland and having visited San Diego in 1996 we decided on a return visit to the southern Californian city. Expedia took care of the booking and when we got to the hotel we were completely blown away by the 350,00 lights which had been erected and switched on for the Christmas period. It was almost unbelievable!! The welcome from the staff was warm and helpful and they remained so throughout our eleven night stay. We had been attracted by the fact that accomodation was in bungalows as opposed to rooms in a multistorey hotel and although the outside was rather unprepossessing, the facilities in the bungalow were very good. The resort itself was well laid out and with five swimming pools there was never a problem finding somewhere to have a dip even in December!! The temperatures were always in the low - mid 70s from about 8.30am until around 7.30pm so swimming was always an option. We did not hire a car as we wanted a relaxing holiday and we had discovered that the excellent public transport service passed the door of the resort. Buses nos 8 and 9 rune every 15 minutes during the day and approx 30 minutes in the evening and a 3 or 4 day pass was excellent value for $9 or $15. The city of San Diego was as good as we remembered it and the people were as friendly as the hotel staff. The Zoo in Balboa park, visits to Coronado and La Jolla were all highlights and we had a magnificent holiday. We cannot recommend this resort highly enough.

Reviews.Title: “Better than Expected”
Reviews.Author: Pexster
Reviews.Content: I lived in San Diego most of my life, and after moving to Monterey for family reasons, still like to return regularly for some "face time" at the office. I was a little dismayed at finding myself booked here (a "Name your Price" selection), as I had read some negative reviews and knew how old the property was. But I was pleasantly surprised at the nice room. Internet connectivity was fine (which is critical for me), the shower was GREAT, and the food was really good. Downsides? The TV was small and old, and the local channels suffered from bleedthrough of the nearby Mt. Soledad towers into the cable. This made them pretty much unwatchable, and the cable offerings are slim. The $20 per day to park is irritating, also. I have never before paid to park on a property where you drive to your room. It's like a motel charging to park. Come on! Another thing to note for the business traveler. The location is right next to Sea World, which is an area of SD that is hard to get in and out of during rush hours (especially if you need to head north). Not an issue if you get moving before 6:30-7:00 or so, though.

Reviews.Title: “Overpriced place”
Reviews.Author: prettee2000
Reviews.Content: We stayed 2 nights at Paradise Point. Though the concept of having a vacation resort is great, I don't think the resort came upto my expectations. The room we stayed in was with a double bed and looked decent. The bathroom and the vanity area had tiles on the floor. The floor was cold and I think the management should have atleast provided a foot mat. Also, I was really surprised that there was no waste basket in the bathroom! Like many of the reviewers have previously stated, the resort compasses a huge area and facilities are spread out. Though the list of facilities is long, not everything looks as appealing.. The spa rates were outrageous.... (a simple pedicure cost $60!!) and the observation tower looked like it had been consumed by rust and would collapse any minute!! The most ridiculous thing was that there was no wireless internet (even motels have them!) and if you needed to use the internet, it was a $10 fee/ day of using the DSL connection in your room! I personally would not visit it again.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Resort”
Reviews.Author: johnnyq627a
Reviews.Content: We stayed at Paradise from Thurs Dec 30 - Sun Dec 3. We were upgraded to a Garden Suite for no charge. The room was extremely large. It had a king bed, armoire with TV, couch with coffee table, breakfast table with four chairs, seperate room with a fridge and microwave, a large walk in closet, tub/toilet in seperate room, double sinks in seperate room. The room itself reminded me a lot of our stay in the Dominical Republic... a very tropical feel, as opposed to high end luxury. The parking fee was $20, but the Marriot in Mission Valley I stayed at the previous nights was $13, so not much different. The grounds were beautiful, lots of diverse plant life, many ponds and lakes with ducks which we enjoyed feeding. The small restaurant had a saltwater lagoon with huge yellowtail in it. Luckily I asked before I tried to fish. (I didn't realize it was a pet pond, I thought it was just an inlet from the bay). The breakfast was kinda lousy, we went to downtown/la jolla/ or oldtown for food. The lobby was beautiful, with fireplaces, which was nice since it was in the low 40's morning/nights when I was there. The first day we walked to SeaWorld, which was a bit of a hike (2 miles or 30mins). There were walkways the entire way and walking over the bridge provides a beautiful view. We took a quick walk on the beach one day, it was clean ... that's pretty much all I ask. Overall, I was extremely pleased with my stay at the resort. I have to imagine the poor reviews come from people who prefer Rtiz Carltons and Bellagio type resorts. This resort is NOT a RITZY place, it's more of a caribean laid back setting. If you go there expecting a relaxing place as opposed to high end lifestyle you will enjoy yourself.

Reviews.Title: “Not for the Business Traveler”
Reviews.Author: TMS08
Reviews.Content: I stayed at this resort for 3 nights while attending a business meeting. Upon entering the resort you are struck by its warm and tropical feel. Unfortunately, the sleeping rooms were not as wonderful. Their rooms are not made for business travelers. There was no distinct desk and the high speed internet access was located near the TV which meant you had to use the computer while sitting on your bed. Generally, the rooms did not appear to be overly clean. There were rust stains and other signs of dirt and/or age. The air condition was controlled by a unit in the room which was so loud that you had to turn the TV up to hear over it. When traveling for work the biggest test is whether you feel comfortable enough in a room to walk around in bare feet like you would at home. Let's just say I'm glad I brougt flip-flops. The conference facilities and catering was wonderful. However, the rooms certainly need work.

Reviews.Title: “Pleasant Stay At Paradise Point”
Reviews.Author: tatin
Reviews.Content: Just returned from a two night stay at Paradise Point. The property is beautifully landscaped as a tropical garden. Lots of bird of paradise plants and other plants that screen the buildings and the roads. Our room was most importantly, clean, and painted a cheerful yellow. The bath had one of those rainshower showerheads which I really enjoyed. There was a sink outside the bath/toilet area. My only criticism is that for two adults and two kids, the two queen bedded room was a little small. Our room looked out over a duck pond which the kids enjoyed. Of the resort facilities we used just the restaurant and the tennis courts. The two breakfasts we ate were very good and eating outside at the Barefoot Bar and Grill which overlooks the marina and the bay was very pleasant. The service was quick and the food was good. Dinner, on the other hand, was not good. The food was poor quality and the inside portion of the restaurant was dated and dingy. The tennis courts were okay. They tended to be wet in places during our stay and the squeegee didn't work properly to soak up the puddles. The net was ragged but not sagging. But the surface was good, no holes or cracks and the lighting system was excellent. The lights were done so that the ball never got lost in the glare. A good stay except for the dinner. (We had tried to eat in Little Italy, no parking. Then we went to the Gaslamp District, again no parking. San Diego needs more parking garages at more reasonable rates.) Overall, I'd rather stay here in a bungalow surrounded by gardens and duck ponds than in a high-rise downtown.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful”
Reviews.Author: reid18
Reviews.Content: I stayed here with my son for four days (my second visit). I can't believe some of the reviews. Did I stay at the same place? The setting is superb. From our garden room we had views across Mission Bay and we were just steps from the beach. We found the whole resort clean and tidy (rubbish, what rubbish?). It is an idyllic place to just chill out and relax. The grounds are superb and just great to wander around. We relaxed several times at the adult only pool, one of many pools dotted around the resort. We had it to ourselves most of the time. Our studio room was absolutely fine, very comfortable and clean. As one previous reviewer commented - the furniture is actually MEANT to look slightly shabby. It's not worn out, it's the style: But this is probably a hard concept for some people to take on board. All the staff we encountered were friendly and helpful. The only slight criticism I would have is that the Baleen Restaurant was very expensive and not really that good. On my previous visit two year's ago it was much better. The Barefoot Grill was good though. We had breakfast there in the sun with views across the Bay. All in all, I would recommend this hotel.

Reviews.Title: “Loved it!”
Reviews.Author: hugjessie
Reviews.Content: I was nervous to stay at Paradise after some of the reviews I had read but I am so happy that I did....what a wonderful place! I was there for a group function and we had such a nice time. Our entire group was close together and it was so nice to be able to meet up on the beach for bonfires or to sit around the beautiful lagoon outside of our rooms. The front desk staff was very helpful and the bellman were very attentive to helping with bags and bringing us to our rooms. I cannot wait to stay at the resort again, a beautiful place!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Reviews.Title: “This place is an expensive dump”
Reviews.Author: H-Holly
Reviews.Content: We just returned from a 4-day stay at Paradise Point and I will never, ever stay there again. The first room they gave us smelled so bad I got a headache after 5 minutes of being in there. It smelled of sewage in that whole area of the property. I went to the front desk and complained and they gave me another room in a completely different area of the resort. It was barely acceptable. When we walked around the resort we saw garbage laying around. The ponds were covered with scum. Paint was peeling off the walls of most buildings. This place looks like it might have been nice about 15 years ago, but was bought by a slum lord who hasn't put a dime into since then. I was desperate for a cup of tea the first morning there so I went to their walk-up espresso cart and had to pay $3.50 for a cup of hot water and a tea bag. This place is a total rip off. Stay somewhere else.

Reviews.Title: “Nice place”
Reviews.Author: tonicurtis
Reviews.Content: We came for a conference and found it to be just fine. Rooms were very clean and spacious, although they could use updating. Staff was more thaqn friendly and helpful. I don't quite understand the negative reviews, we haqd a fine stay

Reviews.Title: “NOT a Resort”
Reviews.Author: Choice95
Reviews.Content: I came home determined to write a review but got busy. Maybe things are better now. "Misleading" is the best word I can use. The hotel lobby s well kept and impressive but that is all. The grounds and guest rooms are not maintained. The pictures on the web site are just false. Yes, the rooms are spacious but the ammenties are there but it is VERY MUCH OVERRATED. The rest of the property needs to catch up with the lobby and the pictures on the website!

Reviews.Title: “Not worth the money”
Reviews.Author: frappy
Reviews.Content: There is no way this place is worth the $250.00 per night. It is old, they try to cover up the place with paint and new carpet but the tub, tile around the tub, floors in bathroom and counters were old. The maid service was terrible, two hours to get towels when they had not returned the used ones they took during maid service. The room we had was next to the service entrance and you could hear the workers in and out. The food in the restaurant was over priced and the service was terrible. I travel three times a year on vacation with my family and this is no way any place I would recommend to any friends or family.

Reviews.Title: “Wouldnt reccomend”
Reviews.Author: Ed L
Reviews.Content: Stayed here after for three nights and was glad to leave. The rooms are tired and in need of a revamp - chipped furniture, dirty small patio area outside the room which I would not have sat in , and non working light bulbs not replaced during stay. Had room service one night, ( terrible soggy pizza) and the tray sat outside my room for two days.This was after placing an order only to be told we had the old room service menu and having to make a further two phone calls to get an updated version. No do not disturb signs in this place for some reason, so the maids constantly trying to look round the curtains into the rooms in the morning. Cleaning outside the rooms starts very early and noisily at 7am- just what you want ona vacation I liked the waterside restaurant, nice location especially in the evening, very friendly staff here. Didnt try the more expensive option. Staff seemed to be constantly moving round on golf carts- doing what I do not know. No pool side service- why? Probably acceptable if you have kids , get a good deal and are going to Sea World, which you can walk to- otherwise there is little reason to stay here.

Reviews.Title: “Great! Nice place to stay with the kids.”
Reviews.Author: CAMENDOZA
Reviews.Content: We relly enjoyed our stay here. It was really close to all the activitys outside of the area ( sea world just down the road) The room was great, just outside our room was a pond with a couple of ducks ( that the kids loved) and some mornings a white crane. The main pool was great for kids too...very shallow at one end.

Reviews.Title: “Great for families. "OK" overall”
Reviews.Author: Winfield_Travel
Reviews.Content: We stayed at Paradise Point for about a week after the Labor Day holiday. The property is great for families, as there are lots of kids and kid-friendly activities (feed the ducks, swimming pool a 0 grade that eventually deepens). They set up a Pack and Play in the very large walk-in closet that became our 2 y/o's "own room." Hotel grounds were nice, but not "pristine" or particularly serene. It was definitely tropical in feel, but there's no mistaking it for a secluded island retreat, as some have suggested. The tropical theme does not extend into the guest rooms, which is a little strange. The decor is light and colorful, but much more reminiscent of Cape Cod than Hawaii. Some have criticized the armoirs in the room as old, dirty and in need of a paint job. That's the way it's SUPPOSED to look, but it is not particularly aesthetic. The room was large enough, the furniture too big for the space. We found the a/c to be effective at cooling, albeit loud. Same goes for the mini fridge-- also keeps you up at night. Location was nice. Especially convenient to Sea World, though it would be nice if they ran a shuttle. I can understand why people are upset at having to pay $20 a night for parking (they comped us b/c we checked in as the place emptied out after the Labor Day holiday), but it allows them to advertise competitive room rates. We did not have problems with light flooding the room in the a.m. We had blackout curtains on your sliding glass door and a wood front door. But I noticed not all rooms were this way. We also didn't have dirty carpet, as some complained of. Paradise Point offers a very interesting hotel concept. It is in need of some updating, but overall we enjoyed ourselves. However, if you're paying well above $200 a night on average, you are not getting a good deal for your dollar.

Reviews.Title: “Guests to pay $20/day for parking”
Reviews.Author: kg95
Reviews.Content: This resort is ok, but if you don't want to have to pay $20 a day for parking (even though you're a "guest") or pay $10 a day for internet, then you probably don't want to stay here. The room has a country feel to it, which isn't bad. And, if you stay in the Lanai Patio rooms, then all you get is the window to your patio and no other windows. If I had seen that on their web site, we probably wouldn't have taken it. But we've decided to take the attitude of "we don't want to spend the whole time in the room anyway." But, if you like a little more in your room, then you may want to dish out a little more $$ for a room with a little more. Like I said, the resort is ok for what it is.

Reviews.Title: “Paradise Lost”
Reviews.Author: travellingman2
Reviews.Content: Had 2 rooms (792-793) on Hibiscus Lane. We booked for 3 nights (Sept 6-7-8). Was very specific and had requested way in advance for adjoining renovated rooms having heard some of the comments on Trip Advisor. Check in experience on the night of 9/6/06 should have forewarned me. The rooms are so oudated, carpets are so badly stained, grout dirty, toilets espcially behind the toilet seat grimy. We always bring Lysol and clean for ourselves anyway., but this was too much .The beds were very high to reach. The furniture including nightstands were extremely small and the armoire needed major repainting. When I complained about the condition of the 2 rooms, the front desk said this was the "rustic look". Looked filthy and worn down to me. Very different from what the web-site looked. If you are in to the "Cottage worn-down distressed look", this is the place for you. As far as I was concerned the rooms needed MAJOR renovation and upkeep. The new conference hall (Sunset Ballroom) where we had our meeting is beautiful and sparklingly clean. The deck facing the bay was gorgeous. Alas if only the guest rooms were of the same class and vintage, we would have stayed all the 3 nights. We just couldn't stand it so we had to hassle & check out the next day and stayed at the nearby Hilton San Diego Resort which was cleaner, brighter and easier to manage. The Hilton San Diego Resort was just purchased by the same owner of the Paradise Point.

Reviews.Title: “It was the place for us”
Reviews.Author: Monilad
Reviews.Content: Wonderful stay! We spend 4 wonderful days the end of August. I was with my 81 year old Mother and 14 year old son and we found something fun to do for everyone! Check-in wasn't the best. First gave us the wrong room. We then walked all the way back to the office dragging our luggage. Our room then wasn't ready. We went to sea world and when we returned many hours later room still wasn't ready. I need to say the room was worth the wait. Very comfortable beds, bath products to die for and a view of a duck pond that was breath taking. Food was good, including room service. Pool service and the pool its self was great. A little costly drinks and food at the pool. We loved the grill for any meal. I will always remember watching my Mother and son play putt-putt golf and all the laughs. I was expecting a little warmer bay water but we still managed to go wading. The grounds were wonderful for anytime of the day walks or even resting at a bench. So tropicial. We had a wonderful evening one night watching a dive in movie at the pool. (first my Mother had ever seen) All of the staff in general bent over backwards to make sure we had a great stay. All in all we will be back!!!!!

Reviews.Title: “Not Just For Families With Children”
Reviews.Author: AlCatraz
Reviews.Content: We are a couple (from Scotland) with no children, who stayed for 5 nights at the resort between 20-24 August. We knew that this a 'family' resort before we booked so weren't surprised to be surrounded with small children on arrival but we were pleasantly surprised with the peace and quiet available at the 'Adults Only' pool. We have stayed at some quality adult resorts in the Carribean that have much noisier pools. On the negative side, the car park fees at $20 per night are extortionate, but all American hotels tend to rip-off guests with cars, don't they? We had to pay $28 per night in Santa Monica! The room was as expected, dirty carpet, what do you expect when most guests spend their time at the pool or on a sandy beach? The air conditioning was noisy at night and the room could have done with a paint job, but overall we were very satisfied. The Balleen restuarant was very good, although beware, there are lots of noisy kids there in the evening if you are looking for a quiet and romantic dinner. There are lots of ducks and other animals around, we saw a skunk one evening and the atmosphere is very relaxing. We were unable to get internet access because the Business Centre was closed, but the concierge desk put us in touch with a good Internet Cafe in Pacific Beach. Would we return? Probably yes, given the location and access to San Diego's attractions. Regards Cathy & Ian Gunn

Reviews.Title: “Could not take a 2nd day”
Reviews.Author: lilrags
Reviews.Content: You can believe those other reviewers who said, this place needs lots of attention. It is clear the owners are just raking in the tourist dollars w/o reinvesting any back into the property. The lobby furniture is old and dirty, the lagoon is closer to a swamp. The walls in the rooms are paper thin, with many noises during the night coming from inside the room (the old refridgerator, old air conditioner, and old squeaky bed). This is no place for a light sleeper or persons without children. One positive was the resturant, good service and food. hotel workers were nice enough, although I needed a supervisor to approve cancelling my second night without charge. You see not only do they have a 7 seven day notice to cancel w/o charge, there is a 48 hr notice to change the current reservation. while i made reservations for 2 nights in less than 7 seven days i was required to pay one night in advance....when i wanted to check out (since we could not sleep a wink the first night) the front desk kindly stated that you may leave, but warned I'd be charged for the 2nd night anyway. they put up a small fight, but relented after I described how unsatisfactory the rooms (the 2nd room change) were.

Reviews.Title: “disappointed in Paradise”
Reviews.Author: christylmc
Reviews.Content: My husband and I took our two sons, ages 8 months and 21 months, on vacation to San Diego. We chose to stay at Paradise Point, as we stayed there a year ago and really enjoyed it. This stay was very different, though. The line at check-in was over 40 minutes long, which seemed like forever when waiting with two tired kids. After spending less than 10 minutes in our room I noticed that the bottoms of our feet, and our babies hands and knees were black from the dirty carpet. We had to lay a blanket on the floor for them to play on the rest of the vacation. We asked for a crib at check-in (we had brought one with us, but needed a second to accommodate our 2 boys)...four hours and four phone calls later we finally got our crib at almost 9pm. Room service was prompt, but the food was marginal at best. On a positive note, the pools were enjoyable when they weren't too crowded. The grounds were nice to walk around, except for the room service trays that had not been picked up from outside various rooms. However, we will not be returning to Paradise Point again- this hotel needs some serious maintenance and upgrading!

Reviews.Title: “Dont Bring a Car”
Reviews.Author: GandalfasWell
Reviews.Content: Loveley setting , great water sports and facilities , but dreadful check in - - - Not ready at 3pm - 'Come back at 4pm' , Not ready at 4pm - ''We will phone you' They phone at 5 pm - 'Rooms ready' We arrive back at reception at 5.45 - 'Sorry 1 room not ready' Also at Check out try to charge us for 3 cars all at $20 a night (a real rip off) . Restaurant also outrageously expensive but good . But still a great setting so would probably go back

Reviews.Title: “First time at Paradise Point”
Reviews.Author: dandj6inall
Reviews.Content: We stayed here with 2 of our 4 kids, ages 11 and 12. We normally stay at Humphry's half moon bay inn, but were told this was a great family resort. Here is a breakdown of pos and cons: Check in was great. Our phone in request for early check in allowed us to beat the 4:00 p.m. crowed. Rooms were clean and spacious. (Don't think Four seasons, think large apartment). I lwould expect the kitchen to be partially stocked with such itmes as utencils, cork screw, hand towels, possibly popcorn for the microwave. You are welcome to bring food from home, just remember there is only a microwave, small refrigerator and sink. The sofa bed was VERY uncomfortable, yet the bedroom bed (king) was VERY comfortable, my husband who hates hotel beds acctually slept very well! Bathrooms were clean and big, with shower on one side (leaky)and a full bath and toilet on the other, along with two full sinks. The linens were very nice. Housekeeping arrived 10 minutes after our call for more towels and the roll away (comfortable). In room movies - can't pause and no close caption. Room service was quick and well prepared, though remember the 18% gratuity and $3.50 per delivery is added to the bill. Our Garden bungalow was quiet until Sunday morning at 8:00, my 12 year old daughter was woke by 4 screaming children. Bike rental, croquet, ping pong, minature golf ,swimming all available, as well as water sport rental. Bikes ran out quickly. Main Pool was very crowded every day, but it's the only large family pool in the resort. Watch out for extremely fast cart drivers (employees), making housekeeping and room service deliveries! My son was almost hit by one while riding his bike. They need to slow down! Yes, parking is $20.00 per day, but we had our own numbered spot, no searching for a parking spot after a full day at Sea World. We only ate at the Barefoot Grill (room service food comes from here). Very nice staff, good food, good drinks, just watch out for the birds on the patio during the day! The large ones are very aggressive and will steal your food. Overall, a nice resort. A little pricy for what you get. Next trip, it will be back to Humphry's.

Reviews.Title: “Paradise Point not perfect, but still wonderful”
Reviews.Author: mulchmaster
Reviews.Content: My family and I just returned from a 1 week stay and found the resort to be wonderful overall. Much of what I will say has been said before in various reveiws, so folks just have to know what they want. The resort is lush, tropical and very well located in the heart of Mission Bay. Easy access to anywhere in San Diego (once you get the hang of the freeways!) My feeling is that families with children will enjoy it more as it is large and busy with kids. The rooms were nice, clean and really quite quiet given the density of the resort. While we did have a problem with the shower drain, someone came within a few hours to repair. The staff were generally quite accomodating, both at check in and throughout our stay. Prices are high overall. The Barefoot Bar and Grill while very attractive and with good food, was expensive. As were the drinks and the coffee cart. The gift shop has everything but again, like most gift shops very expensive. The best pool in the place is the small but relaxing waterfall pool. Not as busy, but nice to relax and have a drink. Biggest Complaint: $20 per night to park. Its just not necessary! Biggest Compliment: The grounds and atmosphere make it a wonderful getaway. There are ways you can save by going off site (within minutes) to eat or drink, but sometimes you may just want to splurge. I say Paradise Point gets a really bad rap on Trip Advisor and should be rated much higher.

Reviews.Title: “Great for a quick getaway in SoCal”
Reviews.Author: SoCalTravelGal
Reviews.Content: This is one of the best resorts in San Diego. The resort is gorgeous and their "main" pool is to die for. I've been there 5-6 times. Rooms: They are very nice; I've stayed in different ones and they've all been nice. TIP: when making your reservations if you call them and tell them that you're a "Noble Resort" member, if available, they'll upgrade you for free. I paid for the cheapest room & got bumped up to a bayside bungalo which normally go for $500+/nite! TIP: if you like their shampoo/cond/lotions, call front desk and they're happy to give you extra sets to take home. They smell great! Food: Pretty decent. For me, I liked not having to leave the resort. If you're an "out of towner" then you may want to sight see, eat outside the resort, etc. SPA: I've gotten a massage there a few times and each time ended up in pain, so now I don't book massages there anymore. Also, their spa isn't one of the nicer ones, and I think you have to pay to just enter it, which is kind of lame for what they charge. (I'm a big SPA person and have been to some of the finest spas, so I know what I'm talking about!) GYM: Wouldn't know b/c they charge a daily fee to get in. Other resorts (like all inclusives) include that; which is how it should be. POOL: The main pool is awesome; always heated year round 82 degrees. However, once we went there after heavy rains and it was freezing. TIP: The pool is my main reason for going to Paradise Point, so when it was freezing, I complained and they gave us a free $30 dinner. TIP: They charge a lot for parking ($15-18/day), so I typically book the "bungalow breakfast" special on their website; includes free parking & b'fast each day. depending on the time of year you go, it may be a better deal. Service: They're very nice there... Ambiance: It's like being in Hawaii! It's so pretty there. It's great for SoCal residents who just want/need a quick break. If the US had all inclusives, life would be perfect. Since we don't, PP is the next best thing! It's great for couples or w/ kids; anyone will enjoy it. SD has so much to see & do, you'll love this resort!

Reviews.Title: “3-day get away”
Reviews.Author: go2z
Reviews.Content: My wife and teenage son and daughter had a good time at the resort. It was our first visit and basically lived up to our expectations. We would consider returning, but I feel that the rooms are over priced even given the very pleasant surroundings. I think the management needs to take a serious look at what type of resort it "wants to be." It should pick its clientèle carefully, then go after it with more style and amenities(!). Pros: The location and grounds are very good; we found the visit to be very relaxing. The staff (except for our check-in experience) were friendly and helpful. The room was clean and comfortable. We were located within a few seconds of a pool, which turned out to be great. The room was quiet and we didn't hear "pool" noise. We really enjoyed the water sports, which we thought was reasonably priced. We spent time on the resort beaches, which we all enjoyed. Close proximity to downtown San Diego, Mission Beach and Sea World is a big plus. Cons: The were only two restaurants, which, were over priced. The "barefoot" restaurant had large portions and matching prices. Given the large number of families with small children, the resort could cater for this demographic a lot better. Too much wasted food. Our teenagers felt that that, other than the water sports, the resort had very little to offer them! This is a major gap in the resort or maybe they are sending a message. We found a severe lack of "good" restaurants in the local area. My wife and I didn't see that much for adults to do other than enjoying the surroundings (nice, but more is needed). We did not get the types of beds we requested, and were not told about this at check-in - not good.

Reviews.Title: “Wonderful resort, especially for kids”
Reviews.Author: smacthayer
Reviews.Content: I, too, was worried about all the negative reviews I read, but I booked over the internet on the hotel's own website and got a terrific deal. Bed and breakfast (they give you a $36 credit each day) for myself and my two children, ages 10 and 14. That also included parking. Tip -- better rates on the internet. The hotel reservation desk quoted me at least $100 more per night. Upon arrival, I was ready to "do battle" with the snotty staff and have problems with my room. Not so. The check-in staff were friendly and helpful. The room was a delight -- everything was super clean and comfy. The bathroom was great (two rooms helps) and the king sized bed was so comfortable. We did not pull out the couch as my daughter decided to sleep on it "as a couch" and she was fine. That also gave us more room. Breakfast at the Barefoot was really good. Service was quick and friendly. The main pool was a hit with both kids as was the Dive-In Movie night on Wednesday. This is not a hotel for young couples looking for peace and quiet. It really is a family oriented resort. There were many, many children there, and they all seemed to be having a great time. There is a lot to do, and it's not inexpensive, but if you are on vacation, splurge a little and enjoy yourselves. The resort is close to every attraction and the front desk will give you driving directions for everything. We have traveled all over the world and have pretty high expectations and this place was just fantastic. We will go back.

Reviews.Title: “Are we in Bali???”
Reviews.Author: JAB-I
Reviews.Content: The resort is absolutely breathtaking. I requested adjoining rooms for our family of 5 with easy access to the main pool, and was thrilled when I received my requests!! Just steps from the pool with a beautiful lagoon view with a reasonable rate too!! The grounds were constantly maintained and upon returning from sight-seeing every afternoon found very clean rooms!! Even ordered room service one evening while the kids were watching a movie, and everything came in a timely fashion!! I especially loved the lush gardens and the feeling that you are in a remote & tropical resort!!

Reviews.Title: “Paradise Not!”
Reviews.Author: Dahliah
Reviews.Content: I went for what was to be a "girls" weekend. My 9 year old daughter , my cousin and I planned this trip well in advance. The poor service started at the time of check-in althought the person was quite nice, she was clueless. Beachfront vs garden etc. You find out about the high tarriff of $20.00 per night for parking at that time not in all the info I read on their site. At time of check out I was charged $40.00 per night ~another oversight. Our rooms were poorly maintained and worst of all dirty. Sheets had not been changed on the sofa bed between guests. You would almost have to wonder about the bed I slept in since I know the sheets were not changed from night to night. My daughter thought it was a interesting place with the ducks and other items of interest on the grounds. Although young she has travelled quite a bit. She wanted to know if this is what a motel is like. Baleen's had a wonderful menu, have no complaints of their pricing however it took over 1 hour just to get to appetizers. Just a continuation of their poor service. The spa was a nice but afterall wasn't this suppose to be a resort? I travel all the time and I actual found this hotel to have standards lower than some third world countries have I stayed in. Management issued me a return visit gift certificate however it was cancelled "at my request" which again showed how they manipulate. Do yourself and family a favor stay anywhere but there.

Reviews.Title: “I would not go back, ever--Don't waste your time or money”
Reviews.Author: jrconti
Reviews.Content: Simply, it is overpriced. The pictures on their website does not accurately portray the ‘resort’, rooms, grounds etc. The rooms are dark, dank, and the decor hasn't been recently updated. In our room there was not even a full light blocking curtain on our window. Our queen sized bed was uncomfortable and the air conditioner made a terrible rattle all night long, spewing god only knows what into the air. And my bathroom at home looks nicer. And for those who ask, ‘why didn’t they change rooms?,’ we did—and this was the better room. The adult pool that on a Saturday was supposed to have a bar, didn't. And the main pool was murky, yes murky. Although the grounds were tropically themed, not convincingly so. Did I mention the inflated prices? I would not go back, ever.

Reviews.Title: “Do Not waste your money!”
Reviews.Author: karenindiana
Reviews.Content: Our familly of 4 stayed here for 5 days after carefully reviewing the resort website and reading positive reviews several months ago. It was also featured in the travel catalogue "Where to Stay in 2004" so i assumed it HAD to be nice. Don't be fooled! To say we were extremely disappointed when we saw our accommodations is an understatement...and we chose one of the largest beachfront rooms! Outdated, poorly kept, rundown patios...i could go on and on. I hate to complain when it comes to vacation; i'm almost always a happy traveler. But for the wildly expenisve summer prices we feel we were completely misled and, quite frankly, robbed. When i called the San Diego Consierge to see if there was a better resort with available rooms once we arrived, she told me, "i have to be honest, resorts like the one you're in don't update the way they should." We were stuck (and PP demands a 7 day cancellation notice. Now we know why!! No one would stay if they didn't HAVE to). Recent posts on the site have it right -- Paradise Point is like an old Hawaiian hotel from the 70's. My personal opinion is, don't stay in this area at all. It's a tourist trap with a less than nice beach area. We'll never return. We love downtown San Diego and love La Jolla even more. My advice is, stay away from Mission Bay and away from Paradise Point and you'll hopefully have a better experience than we did. (for the record, however, i should point out our 10 year old son thought the place was fine. There were shells and rocks on the beach. That was all he needed).

Reviews.Title: “Relaxing Get Away, Beautiful Grounds”
Reviews.Author: SanDiegoMoodGoddess
Reviews.Content: I must confess I was a little hesitant to book my 35th birthday "treat" get-away at Paradise Point after reading the reviews on this and other sites. I was pleasantly surprised with the quality of service, the friendliness of the hotel and spa staff, and with the rooms themselves. If you take a car, yes you will have a $20 per night fee tacked on to your room charge. One bonus, however, is that your marked spot is IMMEDIATELY outside your little bungalow -- no hiking through a parking garage. We couldn't afford the more expensive rooms for two nights, so we went with the cheapest available. When we arrived, the room was clean, cool and quite nicely and comfortably furnished. Unfortunately, it faced the parking lot. We called and asked if there were any other available rooms that didn't face the parking lot (it was my birthday, yada yada...) They immediately rebooked us into another room that faced one of their many duck ponds. I thought that their signature restaurant Baleen was very good, if expensive. Their pool was crowded, but we didn't even try to go to any of their 4 additional pools because we were lazy and simply sat in the sun drinking pina coladas. I popped into the spa for one of their facials and pedicures (great experience for both my 6 year old daughter and myself). Anyway, I really liked Paradise Point. Everyone was very friendly and my family and I had a wonderful time. That being said, it's a completely different experience than the Ritz/Four Seasons (much more family directed) and more relaxing than anything you can find in the Gaslamp/Downtown San Diego. Just don't go expecting glitz or refinement. Go if you want a tropical get-away on 44 acres of green grounds and blue bay 10 minutes from San Diego.

Reviews.Title: “Beautiful Resort!”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: I just returned from an extended stay a this resort and we absolutely loved it!! It is certainly named appropriately,"Paradise". My two young boys said that it is their "most favorite hotel ever". Apparently it has now surpassed their previous favorite, the J.W. Marriott in Scottsdale Arizona. My four year old kept asking, "Are we in Hawaii?" .The sevice was fantastic!! The rooms were wonderful. The Barefoot Bar and Grill has fantastic meals, along with great atmosphere, including a live band. The resturant is nestled amongst thick vegetation, a water fall and lagoons packed with tigar sharks and huge fish. We watched fire works nightly from across the bay, while roasting smores on the beach. I can honestly say that for the first time on vacation I could not wait to get back to the resort when we were away. we loved it so much we are changing reservations and staying again next month!

Reviews.Title: “70's Hawaiian Tiki Palace”
Reviews.Author: reallypickylady
Reviews.Content: I had chosen this hotel on a recommendation of a friend who'd lived in San Diego years ago but decided to cut it short due to reviews on this site and booked the rest of our stay at the Lodge at Torrey Pines. However, I was unable to cancel outright because they require a SEVEN day advance in the summer months. Very disappointing. We came in late in the afternoon and was somewhat less let down than expected. Our room (beachfront) was nicely decorated and seemed updated. The toilet made noise all night and the pull out sofa bed was like sleeping on cardboard but otherwise OK. The bay is dirty and so is the beach. They should considering having staff clean the beach daily. I was grossed out and didn't let my daughter get in the water. The lobby smells like a musty motel and could use some revamping. The landscaping is lush but has that 70's Honolulu Hilton feel. We had dinner at the casual restaurant - very over priced for Chili's level food but the setting right on the water was very pretty. This place is a tourist trap designed for one time visitors. At these prices, it should be much better.

Reviews.Title: “Very satisfied”
Reviews.Author: LoveTravelLuvNewYork
Reviews.Content: We got a really great rate for this hotel on Priceline last minute. Stayed here 3 nights. We were very satisfied with everything, especially for the price. Overall impression: I loved the property. It is so big and beautiful. Very impressive. The variety of plants and trees is fantastic. Well-kept. The air is fresh, you can smell the aromas from the plants as you walk around. That is a definite strong point. But, if you're looking for a glamorous room, don't look for it here. Although the room had old furniture and had signs of prolonged wear, it was clean. The bathroom is good and clean. I really can't complain about anything except that it's simple and not brand-new. But I think that the worn furniture is the intended "vintage" style of the hotel (Polynesian theme). Parking is $20 a day. Right outside your bungalow. Our bungalow was stand-alone, so no problems with noise. We had the cheapest room (price is classifed according to beach or garden view), with garden view, which is fine. This place is great for people with children because there are a lot of activities, plus the large territory is great. I would definitely come back here with kids. Since we don't have kids, we didn't spend much time in the resort itself but used it more as a base for exploring SD. The location is good, central for all the exploring. The customer service was very good, very attentive and pleasant. No problems with checking in or anything. Quick to respond to all our requests and needs. They even waived the internet charge of $10 per day for me. I really was satisfied with my stay here. Here are the bad points: --the bed squeaked A LOT, with every minor movement (I had read that other guests before us had the same problem) --the room itself is no more than about 3-star quality--will significantly benefit from a good renovation My husband & I really enjoyed our stay here. However, we would not pay more than $200 per night to stay here. Thanks everyone for writing and keep writing! Thank you Trip Advisor!

Reviews.Title: “Lower Your Expectations”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: We just finished a 4th of July weekend trip here with our toddler and other family. It was decided afterwards that if we just thought of the hotel as a condo facility- meaning no service, no courtesy, do it yourself room cleaning, and the like- we would have been much happier. Arrived at 3 p.m. for 4 p.m. check in and was told the room wasn't ready yet, which was ok because we were early. However room was not ready until after 7 p.m. with no explanation other than to recant and say check-in "starts: at 4 p.m. They wouldn't even tell us where our room was so we could park the car nearby- we were told to just use the parking lot and wander (for four hours with a two-year-old?).Multiple requests led to no crib either. When it did arrive we were provided with queen size sheets for a portable crib. We were offered no compensation or deals either. Room cleaning was sketchy- used items (coffee, lotion) were not replaced daily, nor was the room really cleaned. The same pre-existing dirt was there when we left too. Room service was also incredibly slow and we had an old menu which led to many ordering frustrations (and repeated requests for an updated one were never met). All of this from a supposed family resort. Would definitely not stay there again- paid over $550 a night and they didn't even seem to want us there.

Reviews.Title: “Terrible Service -- Not Worth the Money”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Our family of four stayed at the Paradise Point Resort over the July 4th holiday. Now we've stayed in everything from a Best Western to a suite at the Four Seasons Las Vegas, and I've never encountered such bad service. Maybe because it was the holiday, but surely spending over $800 a night for a room would render decent service and a decent room. I had to call 3 times for housekeeping to make up the room each day. Not only that, but our air conditioner started flooding the room and all the concierge would do was have housekeeping drop us by a dozen towels for us to lay down on the floors ourselves. Since they were completely booked, there was no chance of moving. Secondly, the glass sliding door kept on slipping off its hinges. We didn't bother calling the front desk as that would've taken a couple of hours and ended up fixing it ourselves. As far the food goes, the food at the only restuarant on the grounds is terrible. Go elsewhere - LaJolla for example, and go to Whole Foods in San Diego for breakfast/lunch groceries. Another bad point, but not entirely the fault of the hotel, was that we layed wet swimsuits on a chair on our patio to dry. Someone took the clothes and my son's new tevas. This happend between the hours of 11pm and 9am on night. I would not stay here again. Maybe if you have money to burn, it'd be okay, but I for one will not be staying here again.

Reviews.Title: “It's just a so-so place...”
Reviews.Author: practicalpointer
Reviews.Content: I wouldn't return or recommend staying here, unless 3 conditions are met: (a) you are traveling with young children (for whom there is plenty to do); (b) you can get a guarantee from the hotel that you will be given a room without any musty, mildewy odor; and (c) the average nightly price falls below $190 or so, including parking. Otherwise, I would recommend the similarly priced, similarly appointed Catamaran Resort Hotel as a better alternative. The Catamaran fronts on Mission Bay (like the Paradise Point), but also benefits from being just across the street from a public swimming beach on the Pacific Ocean.

Reviews.Title: “Sand In The Sheets!!”
Reviews.Author: TravelEscape
Reviews.Content: Don’t disregard the bad reviews like we did!! Paradise Point Resort & Spa does not live up to its name. One would expect the highest level of services from a “resort.” Instead, when we opened the couchbed there was sand all over the sheets! Meaning, they didn’t change sheets in-between guests. Totally nasty and unacceptable. So that night we put a small mark on our sheets. The next night we checked them and they had NOT been changed. Most hotels have a sign if they will not change sheets and towels during your stay. Paradise Point did not have any of those signs. One of the Front Desk clerks was very rude, refused to honor our reservations made a month before for a Bayside Room (saying the hotel was booked up), and told us we could depart the property. A manager finally honored our reservation. They charge $20 PER DAY for parking, when parking is just outside the room but when we got the bill, it was for $40 per day (which we had corrected)! In the bathroom, the shower arm fell to the wall and water sprayed out the side. I wanted to say something nice about this place but every day more and more things went wrong. Beautiful grounds. There are plenty of other resorts to go to in San Diego. They may not be as kid friendly but they have to be better. Paradise Point needs to re-train the staff and housekeepers to provide “resort” level service (since there should be a noticeable difference between a motel and a resort). It would also be nice if they hosed off the old bird poop and grit from the patio furniture.

Reviews.Title: “Paradise point no rooms available”
Reviews.Author: A TripAdvisor Member
Reviews.Content: Let me start by saying that I am a travel agent and have traveled and seen a good bit. I arrived at Paradise Point (they did not know that I was doing a sight visit) after a very long night of traveling with my 10 year old and my husband. ( I had called the resort prior to arrival to confirm my reservation as well as to let them know that I would be arriving very late in the evening. ) They had overbooked the hotel and had no room for my family. It is 3:00 in the morning our time. After about an hour of them (Norman) calling around for a room somewhere else they sent us to the BAHIA. They had 1 room available. The grounds here are very nice but it is not a resort. It is a motel. Hot, Dirty, worn, and Old. I was told by Norman at Paradise Point that as soon as I woke I could come back and check into my room.....so after no sleep I called around 9:00 a.m. and was told that check in was 4:00. I explained everything to the front desk clerk and she said "sorry..........come on by and we'll buy you lunch... but check in is 4:00. " Long story short.............they did not charge me the $20 parking every day and they took off a charged dinner on my bill. Would I stay here again? Probably not. It is more important to me to be reassured a room when I am traveling with my family. On top of that, I should have been handled by a manager....but it seems that this happens all of the time at Paradise Point so nothing special is done. The rooms are old, just like many of the write ups say. They are very worn and could use as much attention as the grounds get. We did have a room on a little pond with ducks. This kept my 10 year old busy. The bed squeeked, the sofa bed was VERY thin, I cloroxed the bathroom........it wasn't clean enough for me. Everything in the room is worn from years of use. The carpet is very old and dirty. Bring flip flops or slippers .....my sons feet were BLACK from walking around the room barefoot. The grounds here are beautiful. The barefoot grill was very good and has great atmosphere. The staff was pleasant at all other times. It is kid friendly...just not top notch like their rates suggest. Good luck if you go.

Reviews.Title: “A total letdown after a great trip”
Reviews.Author: nrh
Reviews.Content: We spent the last four days of a whirlwind two week tour of southern California at Paradise Point. Our first week, we were at the Marriott Residence Inn in Hotel Circle which was a perfect base for all our amusement park hopping. Then up to Irvine's Hyatt Regency for a karate tournament. I will review these properties too, but suffice it to say that they met or exceeded our expectations. Unfortunately, Paradise Point did not. Our plans had been to spend the last few days of our trip lounging in the deck chairs in front of our beachfront bungalow next to a pristine (or at least well maintained beach) while our preteen boys played on the beach and in the water. When we arrived to check in, we were soooo excited. The grounds were lovely. The pools were pretty. The ponds were great and we loved the fact that there were sweet little ducks swimming around everywhere (we didn't know that we'd spend the next four days yelling at other people's kids not to throw rocks at the ducks, but I guess that's besides the point!). Our room wasn't quite ready for us, so we took the map the girl at the front desk gave us and went off to check out the general area where she told us our room would be. The first thing I noticed was that the "beach" in the picture wasn't exactly what I expected, it was more of a manmade cove - no waves - big drainage pipe spewing who knows what into the water with a warning sign not to swim within 72 hours after a rain - one stretch with no sand, just a huge wall of boulders. I became concerned about the specific location of our room (i.e. was it going to be near the sewage pipe or the boulders?) and went back to the desk to ask. The clerk didn't know, but when I told her that putting my two pre-teen boys near those boulders was a trip to the emergency room waiting to happen (I'm sure she heard "lawsuit" although I didn't say it) she said she'd put in a request in the back. When they called us to tell us our room was ready, we picked up the keys to Unit #526 (located comfortably between sewage pipe and boulders) and were pleasantly surprised to find that our room was quite lovely. The bathroom was set up so the kids needn't wake us in the middle of the night to potty (unlike the Marriott). The masterbedroom didn't have blackout curtains, but the thick shrubs shaded the windows nicely for late mornings. (On a side note, the thick shrubs only lasted two nights. For some reason they sent the lawn guy with a ladder and an electic trimmer to cut them down at 7:30 a.m. the second morning we were there. We spent the next three nights hanging every available towel in the room in the windows trying to block out the glaring parking lot lights!) No matter, the kids hit the beach and we hit the deck chairs and that's when I started noticing the trash...everywhere. Pizza boxes, beer cans (and bottles), wrappers, all sorts of nasty stuff, old, moldy towels, abandoned shoes, and so on. I called the front desk to ask them what time of day they came by to clean the beach and they said that it was a, "public beach" and they weren't responsible for cleaning it. Funny how the beach in front of the Hotel Del Coronado is public too, and yet the Del manages to clean it anyhow. So, not wanting to spend the next four days looking at a gross trashy beach, we cleaned our section ourselves. I even picked up a maxipad! #^$^%#%@^%!!!! GROSS!!!! I must have used a whole bar of soap washing my hands (which was never replaced - I'm glad I snagged some from the Hyatt!!)! Some other points...like others have mentioned, the food in the hotel restaurants is mediocre and overpriced and I laugh at whoever said the tuna in my salad was "sashimi grade". It should have been in a can. The beach is definitely a public beach. It is located next to a public park where some unsavory elements tend to hang out until half past late in the evening (we once had to listen to heavy bass from car speakers past 3 a.m. - another time they were shooting off bottle rockets!) The hotel staff once again can not help with this situation. The hotel doesn't keep the beach clean with the exception of when they are preparing for their beach karaoke night. They did manage to pick some of the trash (which was overflowing the cans) up in preparation for making us listen to drunken hotel staff and guests blaring karaoke in the style of the worlds worst American Idol auditions until 10:30 p.m. - so much for our nice peaceful bonfire. When I called to ask what it was about and when it would end, they didn't know. They thought it might be entertainment from one of the restaurants (that we weren't near) or possibly a wedding. It was painfully obvious it was a hotel sponsored function - they even had a last call for their cash bar! They just once again didn't want to claim responsibility for something obnoxious. I feel particularly sorry for the poor people whose lawn they claimed to set up the speakers on. To make a long story longer, instead of spending a lot of time hanging out around the "beach" in front of our $550 plus tax plus $20 for parking (even though every room has its own spot) like we planned, we ended up spending most of our time in other places.
